fields.Title of Contribution: From Pathology to Identity and Back: Making Meaning from Early Christian Martyrdom
fields.Description/Abstract: The analysis of early Christian martyrdom as Christian identity represents a response to earlier ‘pathological’ explanations. Reacting to the perceived moral judgement in earlier scholarship about the abnormality of martyrdom, the 'identity approach’ grounds martyrdom instead in the socio-cultural self-construction of early Christians. However, in interpreting martyrdom primarily as a discourse for identity construction, this approach neglects the existential phenomenon of the martyr. Maintaining the existential implications of martyrdom is critical to anchor discussion of martyrdom as a Christian identity discourse, specifically to understand the gap between the ideological function of martyr discourse—for early Christians and early Christian scholars—and the comparatively infrequent occurrence of martyrdom. Given the early Christian martyr’s pride of place in most common understandings of martyrdom and the present-day persistence of actual martyr-making in many ideological domains, relevant scholarship must attend to what made the martyr individually as well as how martyrdom constituted a form of identity discourse for early Christians. This approach will contribute to our understanding of the dialectical relationship between the phenomenon of martyrdom as identity and as event, as well as challenging the implicit theological claim—and cultural assumption—that religious belief alone makes the martyr.
